source.ebf35b39:
# Making another  dataset now this time it's gonna be having the data for the different files
def get_df_numpy(path) :
    df=pd.DataFrame()
    data=np.load(path)
    df['site1']=data[0]
    df['site2']=data[1]
    df['site3']=data[2]
    
    return df
source.adc0c386:
def make_plot(data=data,id_1=0,id_0=1,types="histogram") :
    target_1=get_df_numpy(data['paths'][id_1])
    target_0=get_df_numpy(data['paths'][id_0])
    if types=="histogram" :
        fig = make_subplots(rows=1, cols=2)

        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=target_1['site1'],name="Site 1"),row=1,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=target_1['site2'],name= "Site 2"),row=1,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=target_1['site3'],name="Site 3"),row=1,col=1)

        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=target_0['site1'],name="Site 1"),row=1,col=2)
        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=target_0['site2'],name= "Site 2"),row=1,col=2)
        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=target_0['site3'],name="Site 3"),row=1,col=2)

        fig.update_layout(height=800, width=1200,barmode="stack",template="presentation")
        return fig
    if types=="line" :
        fig = make_subplots(rows=2, cols=1)

        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=target_1['site1'],name="Site 1",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=1,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=target_1['site2'],name= "Site 2",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=1,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=target_1['site3'],name="Site 3",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=1,col=1)

        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=target_0['site1'],name="Site 1",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=2,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=target_0['site2'],name= "Site 2",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=2,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=target_0['site3'],name="Site 3",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=2,col=1)

        fig.update_layout(height=800, width=1200,barmode="stack",template="presentation")
        return fig
    
    
def make_plot_from_array(average_1,average_0,types="histogram") :
    if types=="histogram" :

        fig = make_subplots(rows=1, cols=2)

        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=average_1[0],name="Site 1"),row=1,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=average_1[1],name= "Site 2"),row=1,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=average_1[2],name="Site 3"),row=1,col=1)

        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=average_0[0],name="Site 1"),row=1,col=2)
        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=average_0[1],name= "Site 2"),row=1,col=2)
        fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x=average_0[2],name="Site 3"),row=1,col=2)

        fig.update_layout(height=800, width=1200,barmode="stack",template="presentation")
        return fig
    if types=="line" :
        fig = make_subplots(rows=2, cols=1)

        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=average_1[0],name="Site 1",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=1,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=average_1[1],name= "Site 2",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=1,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=average_1[2],name="Site 3",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=1,col=1)

        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=average_0[0],name="Site 1",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=2,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=average_0[1],name= "Site 2",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=2,col=1)
        fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=average_0[2],name="Site 3",x=[i for i in range(4096)]),row=2,col=1)

        fig.update_layout(height=800, width=1200,barmode="stack",template="presentation")
        return fig

source.4ae4347b:
# Subtracting the values for target 1 and target 0

difference = average_1 - average_0

fig=go.Figure()
fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=difference[0],name="Site 1",x=[i for i in range(4096)]))
fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=difference[1],name= "Site 2",x=[i for i in range(4096)]))
fig.add_trace(go.Line(y=difference[2],name="Site 3",x=[i for i in range(4096)]))


fig.update_layout(height=800, width=1200,barmode="stack",template="presentation")

source.aad9b80f:
What is black hole ?
A black hole is a region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing—no particles or even electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from it. This is something from google.
But for me black holes have always been something that piqued my interest and fascinated me. It could be since it's something i had very low knowledge about or just because of what it can do (in childish language "eat everything it can").

This competition is amazing since it's let me learn a lot more about the black holes and also provides data to get a better understanding about the black holes on my own and explore some unexplored lands .

So what's a binary black hole?
Binary black hole is formed when 2 black holes merge together (interesting right).The orbit around each other. Right before we knew about the binary black holes it was believed the black holes can be super massive in size or just small but intermediate size black holes were believed to exist with no proof but after the first time the gw signals were recieved travelling several light years it was proved that intermediate size black holes were also there in the form of binary black holes .
source.c39ef776: Something that can be seen here is that the signal for site 1 was huge at first meaning that there was a huge difference in the values of target 1 and target which shows a decrease in teh difference as the time goes on which means as the time goes on the strength of the signal gw) weaskens hence making the difference between the target 1 and 0 smaller as well hence making a difference. So as per this logic we should always see a huge difference at the start of the 2 minute span and that will become smaller as the time goes on . This patter is seen on all sites . In site 2 the difference is big at first and the decreases by time and suddenly increases again.
source.ce7b54be: The histogram on the left is the histogram for the target 1 and on the right is the histogram for target 0 . When the target is 1 it can be seen in the above plot that the peak of the histogram is much more spread than the peak in target 0 which means that when the target is 0 the gw waves have values mostly zero but when the target is 1 then there are waves with values other than 0 which contribute to the peak of the data.
